subject: Re: [junit] Test Suites Useless?

messageBody:
On Sun, 4 Feb 2001 mrettig@... wrote:
>> Has anyone else found the construction of test suites to be largely a
>> waste of time? IMO, if you use packages properly, then you should
>> never need to construct a test suite.
>Joi Ellis wrote:
>No, not really.  I like having suite() because it allows me to trim out
>tests I don't need to run without having to delete the sources for them.
>I have a number of tests which, unfortunately, require manual intervention
>to click buttons on swing dialogs, and I leave these commented out in
>the suite() method most of the time so that nightly automated tests run
>unattended.
For selectivity on tests, I would use a subclass of TestCase that identifies the test as requiring user intervention. This way you could have different types of runs, such as your nightly run or a simple debug run that requires a user to click the buttons. Or if you use Ant, you can use a patternset to exclude certain tests on the nightly build.

The process of removing/adding tests to the suite is the very process that I try to avoid. What happens if you forget to readd an excluded test method to the suite? You're tests will probably run and give you a false positive.  Since I never use suites, I've never, ever had a false positive due to a coder failing to properly update a suite.

>Suite() methods also allow me to control the runtime order without
>playing games like manually rearranging source code or changing method
>names so that a reflection-based runtime can be coerced into running the
>tests in the order I want them run.
The ordering of methods is one area where suites may be convenience, but this is a rare case.  If the runtime order is worth the extra maintenance and risk, then go for it.

Regards,
Mike
